awd_titl_txt: Behavioral and neurophysiological investigations of individual variation in cue weighting strategies
awd_abstract_narration:
The perception of speech sounds often requires listeners to pay attention to multiple cues at once. The weighting of the relative importance of cues can nonetheless vary across individuals. Little is known regarding the sources of such variation, however. This project will investigate potential mechanisms underpinning such variability. The project will broaden the empirical database on which theories of speech perception and production are grounded as well as providing insights into first/second language acquisition and pedagogy in terms of the development of personalized training for individual language learners. The project will also introduce young women and under-represented minorities to STEM fields via the study of the language sciences through planned outreach programs. The findings from this project may inform clinical research on developmental or acquired perceptual and language impairments, and may also serve to inform research on speech related technologies.

This project focuses on two potential explanations for individual variability in cue weighting. Listeners might differ in early auditory encoding, which affects the reliability, hence weighting, of certain cues that support phonological contrasts. Listeners might also differ in cue integration strategy such that some utilize a continuous cue integration strategy whereby cue information is integrated as they become available, while others might employ a buffer strategy so that phonemic identification is postponed until all necessary information becomes available. This project will investigate individual variability in cue weighting using brainstem and cortical responses to speech sounds within the same individual, thus providing a comprehensive neurophysiological profile that underlies individual patterns of real-time cue weighting process, as measured with eye-movements.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to explore why individuals perceive speech sounds differently, particularly focusing on how people prioritize various acoustic-phonetic cues. Understanding these differences is crucial for improving theories of speech perception and production and has practical implications for language learning and clinical diagnostics and interventions.

Key accomplishments include:

Empirical Expansion: The project broadened the empirical data supporting theories of speech perception and production, offering new insights into both first and second language acquisition by investigating two main hypotheses for individual differences in cue weighting during speech perception:

a)     Auditory Encoding Differences: We found empirical support for the hypothesis that variations in how listeners' auditory systems encode sounds could affect the reliability and importance of certain cues that distinguish phonological contrasts. We showed that individual differences in subcortical and cortical responses are correlated with individual differences in speech categorization and perceptual cue weighting.

b)    Cue Integration Strategies: We found empirical support for the hypothesis that individuals differ in their approach to integrating auditory cues. When confronted with the same speech signal, some listeners integrate cues continuously as they become available, while others delay phonemic identification until all necessary information is gathered.

c)  Socio-cognition Differences: We found empirical support for the hypothesis that individuals differ in the perceptual cue weights assigned to the speech signal depending on their social evaluation of the talker. Our findings suggest that social biases can lead to variable perceptual outcomes of the same linguistic input.

Broader Impact: The project offers significant insights into first/second language acquisition and pedagogy in terms of the development of personalized training for individual language learners. Our study also has the potential to inform clinical research on developmental and acquired perceptual and language impairments. By examining a wide range of individual differences in auditory encoding and cue integration strategies, our findings provide a comprehensive understanding that can help infer the characteristics of more extreme cases. This insight could lead to more targeted and effective interventions for individuals with speech and language processing impairments, ultimately improving their communication abilities and quality of life.
